Message.Title: THEY ALL SAID, APPLE WAS DEAD...I'M HAPPY THEY WERE ALL WRONG.
Message.Msg: It wasn't fashionable some years ago to like Apple or use Macs. How the world has changed, for the better I might add. Our family is almost 100% on iPads, a couple of iPods too, and three very reliable MacBooks. All of my friends used Windows PCs, many still do, but I have noticed many more Macs in the public eye at various Hot Spots around Richmond. I thought I would never need a PC for myself, and someday I may not, but for now, the bulk of the software I use for digitizing is Windows based. I use Vista, I have learned how to cope with it, actually it does work fairly well, yet not as good as my old 2008 MacBook, still running as strong as ever. I almost bought an iPhone this weekend, then looked at other options and decided to still with what I have for now. I still want one, just not a $80/mo. commitment. I use my land line most of the time. For those who get shaky about holding AAPL let me say from personal, regrettable experience, DON'T, AAPL is a great stock. I sold much too early. Look at it today. With the 50 shares I owned I could do a lot with that as cash. Best to all the old timers, if there are any around. macbooks4us

Topic.Title: Fundamental research method

Message.Msg: As Samsung Electronics Co. goes to court this week with Apple Inc. over product-copying allegations in the biggest market yet, the U.S., both companies' latest quarterly results make clear what's financially at stake. Samsung on Friday announced a record quarterly profit, its second in a row, of 5.19 trillion won ($4.6 billion), up 48% from a year earlier, for the April-to-June period. Its telecom unit experienced a 60% jump in revenue and near-tripling in operating profit, accounting for nearly all of the company's financial improvement.

Topic.Title: iPhone 5 and mini iPad coming less than 2 months

Message.Msg: iMore has heard that Apple is planning to debut the new iPhone at a special event on Wednesday, September 12, 2012, with the release date to follow 9 days later on Friday, September 21. This information comes from sources who have proven accurate in the past. The iPod Mini will be announced at the same September 12 event, as will the new iPod nano.

Message.Title: Rumor: Next-gen iPhone, 'iPad mini,' new iPod nano to debut on Sept. 12
Message.Msg: Published: 06:05 AM EST (03:05 AM PST) An early Monday report claims inside knowledge of an as yet unannounced Apple event that will supposedly usher in the next-generation iPhone, a much-rumored smaller iPad model some have taken to calling the 'iPad mini' and a new iPod nano. Coming on the heels of pictures showing a supposedly fully-assembled next-generation iPhone, website iMore cites sources "who have proven accurate in the past" who claim the three new iDevices will be announced at a special Apple event on Sept. 12. The sources go on to say the sixth-generation iPhone will go on sale on Sept. 19, one week after its purported debut, but a rollout date for the smaller iPad and iPod nano are not yet known. iMore recently reported the iPad mini would be unveiled sometime in October at a sub-$200 price point. Monday's launch date rumor is in line with at least one analyst's projection of an early September launch for the next-gen iPhone and iPad mini, but the tablet was estimated to be released later in the month following an August manufacturing ramp-up. Apple partner Foxconn has reportedly been hiring extra staff to accomodate the influx of iDevice orders and the Chinese company's Zhengzhou plant is said to have already rolled out a few sixth-gen iPhone test batches ahead of mass production. It is unclear where the iPad mini will be built, however, as conflicting reports claim final assembly will take place at either Foxconn's Chengdu or Jundiai, Brazil factories. While the sources didn't offer any additional information regarding hardware specifics, they reiterated the iPad mini will "be exactly like the 9.7-inch iPad, only scaled down to 7.x-inches." The description is identical to earlier "leaked" engineering samples of the device that showed the inclusion of the same 19-pin dock connector widely expected to be introduced with the next-gen iPhone. Not much is known about a new iPod nano, but some sources have claimed the device will eschew its current square-shaped design for something closer to a shrunken iPhone and add a home button.

Message.Title: WOW 3M!!!!!! New Mountain Lion downloads in 4 days
Message.Msg: Published: 08:38 AM EST (05:38 AM PST) Apple's newly updated Mac operating system, OS X 10.8 Mountain Lion, has been purchased and downloaded more than 3 million times in its first four days, the company announced on Monday. “Just a year after the incredibly successful introduction of Lion, customers have downloaded Mountain Lion over three million times in just four days, making it our most successful release ever,” said Philip Schiller, Apple’s senior vice president of Worldwide Marketing. Mountain Lion launched on the Mac App Store last Wednesday as a $19.99 upgrade from Lion or Snow Leopard. It includes iCloud integration, a new messaging application, Notification Center, system-wide sharing, Facebook integration, Dictation, AirPlay Mirroring and Game Center. With sales of more than 3 million copies in the first four days, Mountain Lion marks the most successful OS X launch in Apple's history. Last year, sales of OS X 10.7 Lion topped 1 million in its first day of availability, while total sales had exceeded 6 million by last October. The first public sign of Mountain Lion's success came last Friday, when Chitika Insights revealed that after just 48 hours of availability, Mountain Lion accounted for 3.2 percent of all Mac Web traffic. In just two days, the total usage of Mountain Lion tracked on the Web neared that of Mac OS X 10.4 Tiger. For an extensive look at the features and functionality found in Mountain Lion, see AppleInsider's in-depth Inside Mountain Lion series.

Topic.Title: You Gotta Fade The Gap!! Will Fill Sooner or Later.

Message.Msg: If it`s still up more than 5 at the open, I might scalp fade the gap: short at the 2 min spike, cover at 4 mins. If you have the nerve to hold the short longer it usually reaches its low between 13 and 19 mins. If the gap is +6 it will usually come back down at least 4 (and sometimes all 6) within 13 to 19 mins. before a bull reversal takes it away. Common is 2 mins up 4 mins down 2 mins up to lower high, 8 mins down to LOD or test yesterday`s close. But it really depends on the momentum and why it`s gapping. Sometimes they take days to fill. The scalp fade is frequently a winner...but it will still get your heart pounding!

Topic.Title: Does the Market open up at the price of the "Pre-Market Change" (and NOT the "Close Price" of the previous day)?

Message.Msg: the market will open at the point where PM is trading at the moment of open (can often be quite volatile at that moment). And this point of open will be measured against the previous close just like PM is measured. But sometimes they will just open it at the previous close so they don`t have to do the math from the change of previous day (wink).

Lord Coe, the chairman of London 2012, was accused of breaking a promise that unsold and unused corporate tickets would be given to the public, while Sir Menzies Campbell, an observer on the board of Games organisers Locog, described the situation as depressing. Locog insisted that off-duty soldiers, as well as local schoolchildren and teachers, be taken by bus to venues to help fill the gaps, as Lord Coe ordered an urgent investigation into why so many seats have been empty. A survey by The Daily Telegraph found that at least 12,000 seats were unused yesterday, not including football stadiums, where tens of thousands of seats have been unoccupied for some matches. Popular events such as gymnastics, tennis and swimming had swathes of empty seats despite members of the public being told that they were sold out. While some empty seats were those reserved for dignitaries who did not turn up, others were among 120,000 unsold tickets allocated to foreign countries which have not returned them.

Topic.Title: can some one explain this weird apple rally?

Message.Msg: The uncertainty about earnings and the overall health and future prospects of Apple going into earnings weighed on the stock. Add to that the initial shock of hearing that Apple didn't meet estimates and that's why the stock dropped. But all of that is set against a background of future prospects for this company that are potentially huge and a P/E that has compressed for three years to the point where it would be ludicrous to see it compress further. So with the uncertainty behind us and the earnings lower than expected but still higher on a YoY basis (meaning the trailing 12 month earnings number went up form 41.05 to 42.55, a relief rally was bound to follow and pull the share price back up to what seems to be a reasonable P/E around 14x trailing earnings (about 2 x less than the S&P 500 P/E of 15.9). And with Q3 earnings behind us the market's full attention is now focused on the release of the next iPhone model and the significant likelihood of a new iPod Touch, along with the potential of an iPad mini. If all three are released into the holiday season, the potential for the strongest earnings quarter in the history of all companies would be an odds-on bet. In short, the market looks forward.

Message.Title: Apple to unveil iPhone 5, iPad mini on September 12; iPhone release rumored for September 21
Message.Msg: Apple’s (AAPL) sixth iPhone — constantly referred to as the “iPhone 5” for lack of a better name — is really starting to take shape now that production is ramping up. A fully assembled next-generation iPhone case was shown off in leaked photos over the weekend, and a subsequent report from iMore cites unnamed sources in placing the debut of Apple’s next smartphone on September 12th alongside the “iPad mini” and a new iPod nano as well. Earlier reports suggested the new iPhone will launch on September 21st, so the timing of an Apple press conference on September 12th certainly makes sense. The launch of Apple’s next iPhone is expected to be the company’s biggest iPhone launch yet by just about every analyst that covers Apple, and the $249-$299 iPad mini is seen as taking a huge bite out of Android tablet vendors’ business when it launches this fall.

Topic.Title: Samsung basically already lost their patent battel with Apple

Message.Msg: The South Korean business culture, I learned from my mom who was a business broker leasing small entrepreneurs retail space in shopping centers, is especially frustrating to the American way of doing contracts. First of all, she noted, South Koreans show little respect for commitments or time frames. Their handshake is hollow and meaningless and trying to nail them down to a contractual timetable is pointless. Typically, they'll assert a crafty escape based on intra-cultural misunderstandings, just an excuse because they think they're smarter than everyone else. Indeed, it betrayed to my mom a propensity for dishonesty. The concepts of past, present and future aren't the same to many native South Koreans they way they are to Americans. It's kind of a fused, time-continuum where everything is subject to revision, as they see fit. Dealing with that kind of mindset is treacherous. Look, Samsung clearly benefitted from working as a hardware supplier for Apple before competing with Apple in the SmartPhone wars. They had technical and engineering priority insights into how Apple was designing its products. Somewhere, along the line, they began to believe they "owned" a creative stake in the products they were manufacturing and turned fiduciary and licensing practices on their heads, to benefit themselves and gain an edge they were not entitled to acquire. Trust South Korean business practices at your own peril. These guys are foxy and shifty and they'll conceal and deceive any way they can to make money. Patent theft is simply another ends to a mean for them.

Message.Msg: There's obviously some truth to the title of the article. However, iPhone 5 is still an unknown, so, for all intents and purposes, Samsung is running against an old product. And, while they're currently winning in units sold, their Galaxy s III numbers have been weak and their profit margins still stink. How, you may ask, could I say that the galaxy S III's numbers have been weak. My answer would be that the demand simply isn't overwhelming, especially considering the lack of an iPhone refresh this year *and* the failure of anything named Blackberry. Add to that the Lumia's failure, and 10 million units that the Galaxy S III has moved in 2 months will pale in comparison to iPhone 5's numbers. I expect they'll do 10 million in the first week or two.
